¹ ln Ptolemy's Atlas, lines oi longitude and latitude are drawn, so asto give an appearance ol precision to his mapa, which in reality they do not possess. His conception ol what a map ought to be was derived from Hipparchus, and is thorougbly scientific. Having made these mapa, he drew up a list ol places with the precise latitude and longitude (to the twelnh part oi a degree) assigned to each. But these positione are in the immense majority ol casas purely hypo· thetical, and are determined by the best estimate he could get from travellers' reporta.

considering the immense reputation oi Ptolemy during the middle ages, itis extremely remarkable that Bacon should bave seen so clearly the fallacious character ol this side ol Ptolemy's work, and should show himself so clearly aware oi the necessity lor accurate determination oi the latitude and longitude ol each place by astronomical observation.
